guides.readmeRaw:
# HashiCorp Vault Installation Guide

Enterprise-grade secrets management platform for securely storing and accessing API keys, passwords, certificates, and other sensitive data. Industry standard for secrets management with advanced security features.

## Prerequisites

- Linux system (any modern distribution)
- Root or sudo access
- 4GB RAM minimum, 8GB+ recommended for production
- Persistent storage for Vault data (encrypted disk recommended)
- TLS certificates for production deployment
- HSM (optional, for enterprise compliance)

## Installation

### Using Package Manager (Recommended)

#### Ubuntu/Debian
```bash
# Add HashiCorp GPG key
wget -O- https://apt.releases.hashicorp.com/gpg | sudo gpg --dearmor -o /usr/share/keyrings/hashicorp-archive-keyring.gpg

# Add HashiCorp repository
echo "deb [signed-by=/usr/share/keyrings/hashicorp-archive-keyring.gpg] https://apt.releases.hashicorp.com $(lsb_release -cs) main" | sudo tee /etc/apt/sources.list.d/hashicorp.list

# Update and install Vault
sudo apt update
sudo apt install -y vault

# Create vault user and directories
sudo useradd --system --home /etc/vault.d --shell /bin/false vault
sudo mkdir -p /opt/vault/{data,logs,tls} /etc/vault.d
sudo chown -R vault:vault /opt/vault /etc/vault.d
```

#### RHEL/CentOS/Rocky Linux/AlmaLinux
```bash
# Add HashiCorp repository
sudo yum install -y yum-utils
sudo yum-config-manager --add-repo https://rpm.releases.hashicorp.com/RHEL/hashicorp.repo

# Install Vault
sudo yum install -y vault

# Create vault user and directories
sudo useradd --system --home /etc/vault.d --shell /bin/false vault
sudo mkdir -p /opt/vault/{data,logs,tls} /etc/vault.d
sudo chown -R vault:vault /opt/vault /etc/vault.d
```

#### Fedora
```bash
# Add HashiCorp repository
sudo dnf install -y dnf-plugins-core
sudo dnf config-manager --add-repo https://rpm.releases.hashicorp.com/fedora/hashicorp.repo

# Install Vault
sudo dnf install -y vault

# Setup directories and user
sudo useradd --system --home /etc/vault.d --shell /bin/false vault
sudo mkdir -p /opt/vault/{data,logs,tls} /etc/vault.d
sudo chown -R vault:vault /opt/vault /etc/vault.d
```

#### Arch Linux
```bash
# Install from AUR
yay -S vault

# Or from community repository
sudo pacman -Syu vault

# Setup vault user and directories
sudo useradd --system --home /etc/vault.d --shell /bin/false vault
sudo mkdir -p /opt/vault/{data,logs,tls} /etc/vault.d
sudo chown -R vault:vault /opt/vault /etc/vault.d
```

### Manual Binary Installation
```bash
# Download latest Vault
VAULT_VERSION="1.15.2"
cd /tmp
wget https://releases.hashicorp.com/vault/${VAULT_VERSION}/vault_${VAULT_VERSION}_linux_amd64.zip

# Install unzip if needed
sudo apt install -y unzip  # Ubuntu/Debian
sudo yum install -y unzip  # RHEL/CentOS
sudo pacman -S unzip       # Arch Linux

# Extract and install
unzip vault_${VAULT_VERSION}_linux_amd64.zip
sudo mv vault /usr/local/bin/
sudo chmod +x /usr/local/bin/vault

# Create vault user
sudo useradd --system --home /etc/vault.d --shell /bin/false vault

# Create directories
sudo mkdir -p /opt/vault/{data,logs,tls} /etc/vault.d
sudo chown -R vault:vault /opt/vault /etc/vault.d

# Verify installation
vault version

# Clean up
rm vault_${VAULT_VERSION}_linux_amd64.zip
```

### Using Docker
```bash
# Create directories for persistent data
mkdir -p ~/vault/{data,config,logs,tls}

# Generate TLS certificates for Docker
openssl req -x509 -nodes -newkey rsa:4096 -keyout ~/vault/tls/vault.key -out ~/vault/tls/vault.crt -days 365 -subj "/C=US/ST=State/L=City/O=Organization/CN=vault.example.com"

# Create production-ready configuration
cat > ~/vault/config/vault.hcl <<EOF
ui = true
disable_mlock = false

# Storage backend
storage "file" {
  path = "/vault/data"
}

# HTTPS listener
listener "tcp" {
  address       = "0.0.0.0:8200"
  tls_cert_file = "/vault/tls/vault.crt"
  tls_key_file  = "/vault/tls/vault.key"
  tls_min_version = "tls12"
}

# Cluster configuration
api_addr = "https://vault.example.com:8200"
cluster_addr = "https://vault.example.com:8201"

# Logging
log_level = "Info"
log_file  = "/vault/logs/vault.log"
log_rotate_duration = "24h"
log_rotate_max_files = 15

# Telemetry
telemetry {
  prometheus_retention_time = "30s"
  disable_hostname = true
}

# Enterprise features (if using Vault Enterprise)
license_path = "/vault/license/vault.hclic"

# Performance replication (Enterprise)
replication {
  resolver_discover_servers = false
}
EOF

# Run Vault container with security settings
docker run -d \
  --name vault \
  --restart unless-stopped \
  --cap-add=IPC_LOCK \
  --ulimit memlock=-1:-1 \
  -p 8200:8200 \
  -v ~/vault/data:/vault/data \
  -v ~/vault/config:/vault/config \
  -v ~/vault/logs:/vault/logs \
  -v ~/vault/tls:/vault/tls \
  vault:latest server -config=/vault/config/vault.hcl
```

## Production Configuration

### Enterprise Production Configuration
```bash
# Create comprehensive production configuration
sudo tee /etc/vault.d/vault.hcl > /dev/null <<EOF
# Vault Enterprise Production Configuration

# UI and basic settings
ui = true
disable_mlock = false

# Storage backend - Consul (HA) or Integrated Storage (Raft)
storage "raft" {
  path    = "/opt/vault/data"
  node_id = "vault-node-1"

  retry_join {
    leader_api_addr = "https://vault-node-2.example.com:8200"
  }
  
  retry_join {
    leader_api_addr = "https://vault-node-3.example.com:8200"
  }

  # Enterprise: Performance replication
  autopilot {
    cleanup_dead_servers = true
    last_contact_threshold = "200ms"
    max_trailing_logs = 250
    min_quorum = 3
    server_stabilization_time = "10s"
  }
}

# Alternative: Consul backend for HA
# storage "consul" {
#   address = "127.0.0.1:8500"
#   path    = "vault/"
#   service = "vault"
#   check_timeout = "5s"
#   disable_registration = false
# }

# HTTPS listener with modern TLS
listener "tcp" {
  address       = "0.0.0.0:8200"
  tls_cert_file = "/opt/vault/tls/vault.crt"
  tls_key_file  = "/opt/vault/tls/vault.key"
  tls_min_version = "tls12"
  tls_cipher_suites = "TLS_ECDHE_RSA_WITH_AES_256_GCM_SHA384,TLS_ECDHE_ECDSA_WITH_AES_256_GCM_SHA384,TLS_ECDHE_RSA_WITH_CHACHA20_POLY1305,TLS_ECDHE_ECDSA_WITH_CHACHA20_POLY1305,TLS_ECDHE_RSA_WITH_AES_128_GCM_SHA256,TLS_ECDHE_ECDSA_WITH_AES_128_GCM_SHA256"
  tls_require_and_verify_client_cert = false
  tls_client_ca_file = "/opt/vault/tls/ca.crt"
}

# Cluster listener for HA
listener "tcp" {
  address = "0.0.0.0:8201" 
  cluster_address = "0.0.0.0:8201"
  tls_cert_file = "/opt/vault/tls/vault.crt"
  tls_key_file  = "/opt/vault/tls/vault.key"
}

# API and cluster addresses
api_addr = "https://vault.example.com:8200"
cluster_addr = "https://vault.example.com:8201"

# Enterprise license
license_path = "/opt/vault/license/vault.hclic"

# Logging configuration
log_level = "Info"
log_file  = "/opt/vault/logs/vault.log"
log_rotate_duration = "24h"
log_rotate_max_files = 30

# Telemetry and monitoring
telemetry {
  prometheus_retention_time = "30s"
  disable_hostname = true
  usage_gauge_period = "5m"
}

# Seal configuration - Auto-unseal with cloud KMS (Enterprise)
seal "awskms" {
  region     = "us-west-2"
  kms_key_id = "arn:aws:kms:us-west-2:123456789012:key/12345678-1234-1234-1234-123456789012"
}

# Alternative: Azure Key Vault
# seal "azurekeyvault" {
#   tenant_id      = "46646709-b63e-4747-be42-516edeaf1e14"
#   client_id      = "03dc33fc-16d9-4b77-8152-3ec568f8af6e"
#   client_secret  = "DUJDS3..."
#   vault_name     = "hc-vault"
#   key_name       = "vault_key"
# }

# Alternative: Google Cloud KMS
# seal "gcpckms" {
#   project     = "vault-project"
#   region      = "us-central1"
#   key_ring    = "vault-keyring"
#   crypto_key  = "vault-key"
# }

# Performance replication (Enterprise)
replication {
  resolver_discover_servers = false
}

# HSM configuration (Enterprise with HSM)
# seal "pkcs11" {
#   lib            = "/usr/lib/softhsm/libsofthsm2.so"
#   slot           = "0"
#   pin            = "1234"
#   key_label      = "vault-hsm-key"
#   hmac_key_label = "vault-hsm-hmac-key"
# }
EOF

sudo chown vault:vault /etc/vault.d/vault.hcl
sudo chmod 640 /etc/vault.d/vault.hcl
```

### Advanced TLS Configuration
```bash
# Generate production-grade TLS certificates
sudo mkdir -p /opt/vault/tls

# Create CA certificate
sudo openssl genrsa -out /opt/vault/tls/ca-key.pem 4096
sudo openssl req -new -x509 -days 3650 -key /opt/vault/tls/ca-key.pem -out /opt/vault/tls/ca.crt -subj "/C=US/ST=State/L=City/O=Organization/CN=Vault-CA"

# Create server certificate
sudo openssl genrsa -out /opt/vault/tls/vault-key.pem 4096
sudo openssl req -new -key /opt/vault/tls/vault-key.pem -out /opt/vault/tls/vault.csr -subj "/C=US/ST=State/L=City/O=Organization/CN=vault.example.com"

# Create certificate with SAN extensions
sudo tee /opt/vault/tls/vault.conf > /dev/null <<EOF
[req]
distinguished_name = req_distinguished_name
req_extensions = v3_req

[req_distinguished_name]

[v3_req]
basicConstraints = CA:FALSE
keyUsage = nonRepudiation, digitalSignature, keyEncipherment
subjectAltName = @alt_names

[alt_names]
DNS.1 = vault.example.com
DNS.2 = vault-node-1.example.com
DNS.3 = vault-node-2.example.com
DNS.4 = vault-node-3.example.com
DNS.5 = localhost
IP.1 = 127.0.0.1
IP.2 = 10.0.1.10
IP.3 = 10.0.1.11
IP.4 = 10.0.1.12
EOF

sudo openssl x509 -req -days 365 -in /opt/vault/tls/vault.csr -CA /opt/vault/tls/ca.crt -CAkey /opt/vault/tls/ca-key.pem -CAcreateserial -out /opt/vault/tls/vault.crt -extensions v3_req -extfile /opt/vault/tls/vault.conf

# Set secure permissions
sudo chmod 600 /opt/vault/tls/*-key.pem
sudo chmod 644 /opt/vault/tls/*.crt
sudo chown -R vault:vault /opt/vault/tls

# For Let's Encrypt certificates (production)
sudo apt install -y certbot  # Ubuntu/Debian
sudo yum install -y certbot  # RHEL/CentOS

sudo certbot certonly --standalone -d vault.example.com
sudo cp /etc/letsencrypt/live/vault.example.com/fullchain.pem /opt/vault/tls/vault.crt
sudo cp /etc/letsencrypt/live/vault.example.com/privkey.pem /opt/vault/tls/vault-key.pem
sudo chown vault:vault /opt/vault/tls/vault.*
```

### Enterprise SystemD Service with Security Hardening
```bash
sudo tee /etc/systemd/system/vault.service > /dev/null <<EOF
[Unit]
Description=HashiCorp Vault - A tool for managing secrets
Documentation=https://www.vaultproject.io/docs/
Requires=network-online.target
After=network-online.target
ConditionFileNotEmpty=/etc/vault.d/vault.hcl
StartLimitIntervalSec=60
StartLimitBurst=3

[Service]
Type=notify
User=vault
Group=vault
ExecStart=/usr/local/bin/vault server -config=/etc/vault.d/vault.hcl
ExecReload=/bin/kill --signal HUP \$MAINPID
KillMode=process
Restart=on-failure
RestartSec=5
TimeoutStopSec=30
StartLimitInterval=60
StartLimitBurst=3

# File system isolation
ProtectSystem=full
ProtectHome=read-only
PrivateTmp=yes
PrivateDevices=yes

# Secure computing
NoNewPrivileges=yes
SecureBits=keep-caps
CapabilityBoundingSet=CAP_SYSLOG CAP_IPC_LOCK

# Additional security features
AmbientCapabilities=CAP_IPC_LOCK
Capabilities=CAP_IPC_LOCK+ep

# Resource limits
LimitNOFILE=65536
LimitMEMLOCK=infinity
LimitCORE=0

# Network isolation
RestrictNamespaces=yes
RestrictRealtime=yes

# Read-only paths
ReadOnlyPaths=/etc /usr

# Writable paths
ReadWritePaths=/opt/vault/data
ReadWritePaths=/opt/vault/logs

[Install]
WantedBy=multi-user.target
EOF

sudo systemctl daemon-reload
```

### High Availability Cluster Setup
```bash
# Configure HA cluster with Integrated Storage (Raft)
# Node 1 configuration
sudo tee /etc/vault.d/vault.hcl > /dev/null <<EOF
ui = true
disable_mlock = false

storage "raft" {
  path    = "/opt/vault/data"
  node_id = "vault-node-1"
}

listener "tcp" {
  address       = "0.0.0.0:8200"
  tls_cert_file = "/opt/vault/tls/vault.crt"
  tls_key_file  = "/opt/vault/tls/vault-key.pem"
  tls_min_version = "tls12"
}

listener "tcp" {
  address       = "0.0.0.0:8201"
  cluster_address = "10.0.1.10:8201"
  tls_cert_file = "/opt/vault/tls/vault.crt"
  tls_key_file  = "/opt/vault/tls/vault-key.pem"
}

api_addr = "https://10.0.1.10:8200"
cluster_addr = "https://10.0.1.10:8201"

# Enterprise features
license_path = "/opt/vault/license/vault.hclic"

# Auto-unseal with AWS KMS
seal "awskms" {
  region     = "us-west-2"
  kms_key_id = "arn:aws:kms:us-west-2:123456789012:key/vault-unseal-key"
}

# Performance replication (Enterprise)
replication {
  resolver_discover_servers = false
}
EOF

# Initialize cluster on first node
sudo systemctl start vault
export VAULT_ADDR='https://127.0.0.1:8200'
export VAULT_SKIP_VERIFY=true  # Only for self-signed certs
vault operator init -recovery-shares=5 -recovery-threshold=3

# Join additional nodes to cluster
# Node 2 and 3: Add retry_join blocks to their vault.hcl
sudo tee -a /etc/vault.d/vault.hcl > /dev/null <<EOF

storage "raft" {
  path    = "/opt/vault/data"
  node_id = "vault-node-2"  # Change to node-3 for third node
  
  retry_join {
    leader_api_addr = "https://10.0.1.10:8200"
  }
}
EOF
```

## Security Hardening (2024 Best Practices)

### System-Level Security
```bash
# Disable swap (critical for security)
sudo swapoff -a
sudo sed -i '/ swap / s/^\(.*\)$/#\1/g' /etc/fstab

# Disable core dumps
echo '* hard core 0' | sudo tee -a /etc/security/limits.conf
echo '* soft core 0' | sudo tee -a /etc/security/limits.conf
echo 'vault hard core 0' | sudo tee -a /etc/security/limits.conf
echo 'vault soft core 0' | sudo tee -a /etc/security/limits.conf

# Configure kernel parameters for security
sudo tee -a /etc/sysctl.conf > /dev/null <<EOF
# Vault security hardening
kernel.dmesg_restrict = 1
kernel.kptr_restrict = 2
kernel.yama.ptrace_scope = 1
fs.suid_dumpable = 0
net.ipv4.conf.all.send_redirects = 0
net.ipv4.conf.default.send_redirects = 0
net.ipv4.conf.all.accept_source_route = 0
net.ipv4.conf.default.accept_source_route = 0
EOF

sudo sysctl -p

# SELinux configuration (RHEL/CentOS/Fedora)
if command -v getenforce >/dev/null 2>&1; then
    sudo setsebool -P authlogin_nsswitch_use_ldap 1
    sudo setsebool -P allow_execheap 0
    sudo setsebool -P allow_execmem 0
    sudo setsebool -P allow_execmod 0
    sudo setsebool -P allow_execstack 0
    
    # Custom SELinux policy for Vault
    sudo tee vault.te > /dev/null <<EOF
module vault 1.0;

require {
    type unconfined_t;
    type vault_t;
    class capability { ipc_lock sys_admin };
    class process { setrlimit };
}

#============= vault_t ==============
allow vault_t self:capability { ipc_lock sys_admin };
allow vault_t self:process setrlimit;
EOF

    checkmodule -M -m -o vault.mod vault.te
    semodule_package -o vault.pp -m vault.mod
    sudo semodule -i vault.pp
fi

# AppArmor configuration (Ubuntu/Debian)
if command -v apparmor_status >/dev/null 2>&1; then
    sudo tee /etc/apparmor.d/vault > /dev/null <<EOF
#include <tunables/global>

/usr/local/bin/vault {
  #include <abstractions/base>
  #include <abstractions/nameservice>
  #include <abstractions/ssl_certs>

  capability ipc_lock,
  capability setuid,
  capability setgid,

  /usr/local/bin/vault mr,
  /etc/vault.d/** r,
  /opt/vault/** rwk,
  /proc/meminfo r,
  /proc/sys/kernel/random/uuid r,
  /sys/kernel/mm/transparent_hugepage/hpage_pmd_size r,

  # Network access
  network inet dgram,
  network inet stream,

  # Deny dangerous operations
  deny /proc/kcore rwklx,
  deny /proc/sysrq-trigger rwklx,
  deny /proc/kmem rwklx,
  deny /proc/mem rwklx,
}
EOF

    sudo apparmor_parser -r /etc/apparmor.d/vault
fi
```

### Firewall Configuration (Cross-Platform)
```bash
# UFW (Ubuntu/Debian)
sudo ufw allow from 10.0.0.0/8 to any port 8200 comment 'Vault API - internal network only'
sudo ufw allow from 10.0.0.0/8 to any port 8201 comment 'Vault cluster - internal network only'
sudo ufw deny 8200 comment 'Block Vault API from public'
sudo ufw deny 8201 comment 'Block Vault cluster from public'
sudo ufw enable

# Firewalld (RHEL/CentOS/Fedora)
sudo firewall-cmd --permanent --new-zone=vault
sudo firewall-cmd --permanent --zone=vault --add-source=10.0.0.0/8
sudo firewall-cmd --permanent --zone=vault --add-port=8200/tcp
sudo firewall-cmd --permanent --zone=vault --add-port=8201/tcp
sudo firewall-cmd --reload

# iptables (Universal)
sudo iptables -A INPUT -p tcp -s 10.0.0.0/8 --dport 8200 -j ACCEPT
sudo iptables -A INPUT -p tcp -s 10.0.0.0/8 --dport 8201 -j ACCEPT
sudo iptables -A INPUT -p tcp --dport 8200 -j DROP
sudo iptables -A INPUT -p tcp --dport 8201 -j DROP

# Save iptables rules
# Ubuntu/Debian
sudo apt install -y iptables-persistent
sudo netfilter-persistent save

# RHEL/CentOS
sudo service iptables save
```

### Audit Logging and Monitoring
```bash
# Enable comprehensive audit logging
export VAULT_ADDR='https://127.0.0.1:8200'
vault auth <root-token>

# Enable file audit device
vault audit enable file file_path=/opt/vault/logs/audit.log

# Enable syslog audit device
vault audit enable syslog tag="vault" facility="LOCAL0"

# Configure log rotation for audit logs
sudo tee /etc/logrotate.d/vault-audit > /dev/null <<EOF
/opt/vault/logs/audit.log {
    daily
    missingok
    rotate 90
    compress
    delaycompress
    notifempty
    create 640 vault vault
    postrotate
        /bin/kill -HUP \`cat /var/run/vault.pid 2>/dev/null\` 2>/dev/null || true
    endscript
}
EOF

# Setup centralized logging (rsyslog configuration)
sudo tee -a /etc/rsyslog.conf > /dev/null <<EOF

# Vault audit logging
local0.*    /var/log/vault-audit.log
& stop
EOF

sudo systemctl restart rsyslog

# Prometheus monitoring configuration
vault write sys/metrics/config enabled=true
```

## Authentication Methods and Policies

### Enterprise Authentication Setup
```bash
# Enable and configure LDAP authentication
vault auth enable ldap

vault write auth/ldap/config \
    url="ldaps://ldap.example.com" \
```

### PKI Secrets Engine (Enterprise Certificate Management)
```bash
# Enable PKI secrets engine for internal CA
vault secrets enable -path=pki pki

# Configure CA
vault secrets tune -max-lease-ttl=87600h pki

# Generate internal CA certificate
vault write -field=certificate pki/root/generate/internal \
    common_name="Internal CA" \
    issuer_name="internal-ca" \
    ttl=87600h > /opt/vault/tls/internal-ca.crt

# Configure certificate URLs
vault write pki/config/urls \
    issuing_certificates="https://vault.example.com:8200/v1/pki/ca" \
    crl_distribution_points="https://vault.example.com:8200/v1/pki/crl"

# Create intermediate CA
vault secrets enable -path=pki_int pki

vault secrets tune -max-lease-ttl=43800h pki_int

# Generate intermediate CSR
vault write -format=json pki_int/intermediate/generate/internal \
    common_name="Internal Intermediate CA" \
    issuer_name="internal-intermediate-ca" \
    | jq -r '.data.csr' > pki_intermediate.csr

# Sign intermediate certificate
vault write -format=json pki/root/sign-intermediate \
    issuer_ref="internal-ca" \
    csr=@pki_intermediate.csr \
    format=pem_bundle ttl="43800h" \
    | jq -r '.data.certificate' > intermediate.cert.pem

# Import signed certificate
vault write pki_int/intermediate/set-signed certificate=@intermediate.cert.pem

# Create role for service certificates
vault write pki_int/roles/service-role \
    issuer_ref="internal-intermediate-ca" \
    allowed_domains="example.com,internal.example.com" \
    allow_subdomains=true \
    max_ttl="72h" \
    generate_lease=true

# Create role for client certificates
vault write pki_int/roles/client-role \
    issuer_ref="internal-intermediate-ca" \
    allowed_domains="client.example.com" \
    allow_subdomains=false \
    client_flag=true \
    max_ttl="24h"

# Generate certificate
vault write pki_int/issue/service-role common_name="api.example.com" ttl="24h"
```

## Backup and Disaster Recovery

### Enterprise Backup Strategy
```bash
# Create comprehensive backup script
sudo tee /usr/local/bin/vault-backup.sh > /dev/null <<'EOF'
#!/bin/bash
BACKUP_DIR="/backup/vault"
DATE=$(date +%Y%m%d_%H%M%S)

mkdir -p ${BACKUP_DIR}/{snapshots,configs,certificates}

# Raft storage snapshot (Enterprise)
vault operator raft snapshot save ${BACKUP_DIR}/snapshots/vault-snapshot-${DATE}.snap

# Backup configuration files
tar -czf ${BACKUP_DIR}/configs/vault-config-${DATE}.tar.gz \
    /etc/vault.d/ \
    /etc/systemd/system/vault.service

# Backup TLS certificates
tar -czf ${BACKUP_DIR}/certificates/vault-tls-${DATE}.tar.gz \
    /opt/vault/tls/

# Backup to cloud storage
# AWS S3
aws s3 cp ${BACKUP_DIR}/snapshots/vault-snapshot-${DATE}.snap s3://vault-backups/snapshots/
aws s3 cp ${BACKUP_DIR}/configs/vault-config-${DATE}.tar.gz s3://vault-backups/configs/

# Azure Blob Storage
az storage blob upload \
    --file ${BACKUP_DIR}/snapshots/vault-snapshot-${DATE}.snap \
    --container-name vault-backups \
    --name snapshots/vault-snapshot-${DATE}.snap

# Google Cloud Storage
gsutil cp ${BACKUP_DIR}/snapshots/vault-snapshot-${DATE}.snap gs://vault-backups/snapshots/

# Verify snapshot integrity
vault operator raft snapshot inspect ${BACKUP_DIR}/snapshots/vault-snapshot-${DATE}.snap

# Keep only last 30 backups locally
find ${BACKUP_DIR} -name "vault-*" -type f -mtime +30 -delete

# Encrypt backup files
gpg --symmetric --cipher-algo AES256 ${BACKUP_DIR}/snapshots/vault-snapshot-${DATE}.snap

echo "Vault backup completed: ${DATE}"
EOF

sudo chmod +x /usr/local/bin/vault-backup.sh

# Schedule automated backups
echo "0 2 * * * root /usr/local/bin/vault-backup.sh" | sudo tee -a /etc/crontab
```

```bash
jq -r 'select(.type=="response" and .error != null) | [.time, .request.remote_address, .error] | @tsv' ${AUDIT_LOG} | tail -100 >> ${ANALYSIS_DIR}/failed-auth-${DATE}.txt

# Most active users
echo "Most Active Users - ${DATE}" > ${ANALYSIS_DIR}/active-users-${DATE}.txt
jq -r 'select(.type=="request" and .auth != null) | .auth.display_name' ${AUDIT_LOG} | sort | uniq -c | sort -nr | head -20 >> ${ANALYSIS_DIR}/active-users-${DATE}.txt

# Secret access patterns
echo "Secret Access Patterns - ${DATE}" > ${ANALYSIS_DIR}/secret-access-${DATE}.txt
jq -r 'select(.type=="request" and .request.path | test("^secret/data/")) | [.time, .auth.display_name, .request.path] | @tsv' ${AUDIT_LOG} | tail -100 >> ${ANALYSIS_DIR}/secret-access-${DATE}.txt

# Policy violations
echo "Policy Violations - ${DATE}" > ${ANALYSIS_DIR}/policy-violations-${DATE}.txt
jq -r 'select(.type=="response" and .error != null and (.error | test("permission denied"))) | [.time, .auth.display_name, .request.path, .error] | @tsv' ${AUDIT_LOG} | tail -50 >> ${ANALYSIS_DIR}/policy-violations-${DATE}.txt

# Generate summary report
cat > ${ANALYSIS_DIR}/audit-summary-${DATE}.txt <<EOL
Vault Audit Summary - ${DATE}
==============================

Total Requests: $(jq -s 'length' ${AUDIT_LOG})
Failed Authentications: $(jq -s 'map(select(.type=="response" and .error != null)) | length' ${AUDIT_LOG})
Policy Violations: $(jq -s 'map(select(.type=="response" and .error != null and (.error | test("permission denied")))) | length' ${AUDIT_LOG})
Unique Users: $(jq -r 'select(.type=="request" and .auth != null) | .auth.display_name' ${AUDIT_LOG} | sort -u | wc -l)

Top 5 Accessed Paths:
$(jq -r 'select(.type=="request") | .request.path' ${AUDIT_LOG} | sort | uniq -c | sort -nr | head -5)

Analysis completed at: $(date)
EOL

echo "Audit analysis completed. Reports in: ${ANALYSIS_DIR}/"
EOF

sudo chmod +x /usr/local/bin/vault-audit-analysis.sh

# Schedule weekly audit analysis
echo "0 6 * * 1 root /usr/local/bin/vault-audit-analysis.sh" | sudo tee -a /etc/crontab
```

## Verification and Testing

### Comprehensive Health Checks
```bash
# Create Vault health monitoring script
sudo tee /usr/local/bin/vault-health-check.sh > /dev/null <<'EOF'
#!/bin/bash
VAULT_ADDR="https://vault.example.com:8200"
HEALTH_LOG="/var/log/vault-health.log"

# Function to log with timestamp
log_message() {
    echo "$(date '+%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S') - $1" | tee -a ${HEALTH_LOG}
}

# Check Vault service status
if systemctl is-active vault >/dev/null 2>&1; then
    log_message "✓ Vault service is running"
else
    log_message "✗ Vault service is not running"
    exit 1
fi

# Check Vault HTTP health
if curl -k -sf ${VAULT_ADDR}/v1/sys/health >/dev/null 2>&1; then
    log_message "✓ Vault HTTP endpoint is responding"
else
    log_message "✗ Vault HTTP endpoint is not responding"
    exit 1
fi

# Check if Vault is sealed
SEALED_STATUS=$(vault status -format=json | jq -r .sealed)
if [ "$SEALED_STATUS" = "false" ]; then
    log_message "✓ Vault is unsealed"
else
    log_message "✗ Vault is sealed"
    exit 1
fi

# Check cluster status (if HA)
if vault status -format=json | jq -r .ha_enabled | grep -q "true"; then
    CLUSTER_HEALTH=$(vault operator raft list-peers -format=json | jq '.data.config.servers | length')
    log_message "✓ Cluster has ${CLUSTER_HEALTH} nodes"
fi

# Check replication status (Enterprise)
REPLICATION_STATUS=$(vault read -format=json sys/replication/status 2>/dev/null)
if [ $? -eq 0 ]; then
    DR_MODE=$(echo $REPLICATION_STATUS | jq -r .data.dr.mode)
    PERF_MODE=$(echo $REPLICATION_STATUS | jq -r .data.performance.mode)
    log_message "✓ Replication status - DR: ${DR_MODE}, Performance: ${PERF_MODE}"
fi

# Check auth methods
AUTH_METHODS=$(vault auth list -format=json | jq -r 'keys | length')
log_message "✓ ${AUTH_METHODS} authentication methods enabled"

# Check secrets engines
SECRETS_ENGINES=$(vault secrets list -format=json | jq -r 'keys | length')
log_message "✓ ${SECRETS_ENGINES} secrets engines enabled"

# Check policy count
POLICIES=$(vault policy list | wc -l)
log_message "✓ ${POLICIES} policies configured"

# Test secret read/write
TEST_SECRET="secret/health-check/test-$(date +%s)"
if vault kv put ${TEST_SECRET} test=true >/dev/null 2>&1; then
    if vault kv get ${TEST_SECRET} >/dev/null 2>&1; then
        log_message "✓ Secret read/write test passed"
        vault kv delete ${TEST_SECRET} >/dev/null 2>&1
    else
        log_message "✗ Secret read test failed"
    fi
else
    log_message "✗ Secret write test failed"
fi

# Check audit devices
AUDIT_DEVICES=$(vault audit list -format=json | jq -r 'keys | length')
log_message "✓ ${AUDIT_DEVICES} audit devices enabled"

log_message "Vault health check completed successfully"
EOF

sudo chmod +x /usr/local/bin/vault-health-check.sh

# Schedule health checks every 15 minutes
echo "*/15 * * * * root /usr/local/bin/vault-health-check.sh" | sudo tee -a /etc/crontab
```

### Security Validation Testing
```bash
# Create security testing script
sudo tee /usr/local/bin/vault-security-test.sh > /dev/null <<'EOF'
#!/bin/bash
VAULT_ADDR="https://vault.example.com:8200"
TEST_RESULTS="/tmp/vault-security-test-$(date +%Y%m%d_%H%M%S).txt"

echo "Vault Security Validation Test" > ${TEST_RESULTS}
echo "==============================" >> ${TEST_RESULTS}
echo "Date: $(date)" >> ${TEST_RESULTS}
echo "" >> ${TEST_RESULTS}

# Test 1: TLS Configuration
echo "Testing TLS Configuration..." >> ${TEST_RESULTS}
TLS_VERSION=$(openssl s_client -connect vault.example.com:8200 -brief 2>/dev/null | grep "Protocol version")
echo "TLS Version: ${TLS_VERSION}" >> ${TEST_RESULTS}

# Test 2: Authentication requirements
echo "Testing authentication requirements..." >> ${TEST_RESULTS}
UNAUTH_ACCESS=$(curl -k -s -w "%{http_code}" -o /dev/null ${VAULT_ADDR}/v1/secret/test)
if [ "$UNAUTH_ACCESS" = "403" ]; then
    echo "✓ Unauthenticated access properly denied" >> ${TEST_RESULTS}
else
    echo "✗ Unauthenticated access not properly restricted" >> ${TEST_RESULTS}
fi

# Test 3: Seal status
echo "Testing seal status..." >> ${TEST_RESULTS}
SEALED=$(vault status -format=json | jq -r .sealed)
if [ "$SEALED" = "false" ]; then
    echo "✓ Vault is properly unsealed" >> ${TEST_RESULTS}
else
    echo "✗ Vault is sealed" >> ${TEST_RESULTS}
fi

# Test 4: Audit logging
echo "Testing audit logging..." >> ${TEST_RESULTS}
AUDIT_COUNT=$(vault audit list -format=json | jq -r 'keys | length')
if [ "$AUDIT_COUNT" -gt "0" ]; then
    echo "✓ ${AUDIT_COUNT} audit devices enabled" >> ${TEST_RESULTS}
else
    echo "✗ No audit devices enabled" >> ${TEST_RESULTS}
fi

# Test 5: Policy enforcement
echo "Testing policy enforcement..." >> ${TEST_RESULTS}
vault token create -policy=developer -ttl=1m -format=json > /tmp/test-token.json
TEST_TOKEN=$(jq -r .auth.client_token /tmp/test-token.json)

# Test with limited token
VAULT_TOKEN=${TEST_TOKEN} vault auth -method=token ${TEST_TOKEN} >/dev/null 2>&1
LIMITED_ACCESS=$(VAULT_TOKEN=${TEST_TOKEN} curl -k -s -w "%{http_code}" -o /dev/null -H "X-Vault-Token: ${TEST_TOKEN}" ${VAULT_ADDR}/v1/sys/auth)
if [ "$LIMITED_ACCESS" = "403" ]; then
    echo "✓ Policy enforcement working correctly" >> ${TEST_RESULTS}
else
    echo "✗ Policy enforcement may be misconfigured" >> ${TEST_RESULTS}
fi

# Revoke test token
vault token revoke ${TEST_TOKEN}
rm /tmp/test-token.json

echo "" >> ${TEST_RESULTS}
echo "Security test completed at: $(date)" >> ${TEST_RESULTS}

echo "Security test completed. Results: ${TEST_RESULTS}"
EOF

sudo chmod +x /usr/local/bin/vault-security-test.sh

# Run security tests weekly
echo "0 8 * * 1 root /usr/local/bin/vault-security-test.sh" | sudo tee -a /etc/crontab
```

HashiCorp Vault Installation Guide

Enterprise-grade secrets management platform for securely storing and accessing API keys, passwords, certificates, and other sensitive data. Industry standard for secrets management with advanced security features.

Prerequisites

  • Linux system (any modern distribution)
  • Root or sudo access
  • 4GB RAM minimum, 8GB+ recommended for production
  • Persistent storage for Vault data (encrypted disk recommended)
  • TLS certificates for production deployment
  • HSM (optional, for enterprise compliance)

    • Installation

    Using Package Manager (Recommended)

    #### Ubuntu/Debian

    bash 
    # Add HashiCorp GPG key
wget -O- https://apt.releases.hashicorp.com/gpg | sudo gpg --dearmor -o /usr/share/keyrings/hashicorp-archive-keyring.gpg

# Add HashiCorp repository
echo "deb [signed-by=/usr/share/keyrings/hashicorp-archive-keyring.gpg] https://apt.releases.hashicorp.com $(lsb_release -cs) main" | sudo tee /etc/apt/sources.list.d/hashicorp.list

# Update and install Vault
sudo apt update
sudo apt install -y vault

# Create vault user and directories
sudo useradd --system --home /etc/vault.d --shell /bin/false vault
sudo mkdir -p /opt/vault/{data,logs,tls} /etc/vault.d
sudo chown -R vault:vault /opt/vault /etc/vault.d

    Advanced TLS Configuration

    bash 
    # Generate production-grade TLS certificates
sudo mkdir -p /opt/vault/tls

# Create CA certificate
sudo openssl genrsa -out /opt/vault/tls/ca-key.pem 4096
sudo openssl req -new -x509 -days 3650 -key /opt/vault/tls/ca-key.pem -out /opt/vault/tls/ca.crt -subj "/C=US/ST=State/L=City/O=Organization/CN=Vault-CA"

# Create server certificate
sudo openssl genrsa -out /opt/vault/tls/vault-key.pem 4096
sudo openssl req -new -key /opt/vault/tls/vault-key.pem -out /opt/vault/tls/vault.csr -subj "/C=US/ST=State/L=City/O=Organization/CN=vault.example.com"

# Create certificate with SAN extensions
sudo tee /opt/vault/tls/vault.conf > /dev/null <<EOF
[req]
distinguished_name = req_distinguished_name
req_extensions = v3_req

[req_distinguished_name]

[v3_req]
basicConstraints = CA:FALSE
keyUsage = nonRepudiation, digitalSignature, keyEncipherment
subjectAltName = @alt_names

[alt_names]
DNS.1 = vault.example.com
DNS.2 = vault-node-1.example.com
DNS.3 = vault-node-2.example.com
DNS.4 = vault-node-3.example.com
DNS.5 = localhost
IP.1 = 127.0.0.1
IP.2 = 10.0.1.10
IP.3 = 10.0.1.11
IP.4 = 10.0.1.12
EOF

sudo openssl x509 -req -days 365 -in /opt/vault/tls/vault.csr -CA /opt/vault/tls/ca.crt -CAkey /opt/vault/tls/ca-key.pem -CAcreateserial -out /opt/vault/tls/vault.crt -extensions v3_req -extfile /opt/vault/tls/vault.conf

# Set secure permissions
sudo chmod 600 /opt/vault/tls/*-key.pem
sudo chmod 644 /opt/vault/tls/*.crt
sudo chown -R vault:vault /opt/vault/tls

# For Let's Encrypt certificates (production)
sudo apt install -y certbot  # Ubuntu/Debian
sudo yum install -y certbot  # RHEL/CentOS

sudo certbot certonly --standalone -d vault.example.com
sudo cp /etc/letsencrypt/live/vault.example.com/fullchain.pem /opt/vault/tls/vault.crt
sudo cp /etc/letsencrypt/live/vault.example.com/privkey.pem /opt/vault/tls/vault-key.pem
sudo chown vault:vault /opt/vault/tls/vault.*

    Enterprise SystemD Service with Security Hardening

    bash 
    sudo tee /etc/systemd/system/vault.service > /dev/null <<EOF
[Unit]
Description=HashiCorp Vault - A tool for managing secrets
Documentation=https://www.vaultproject.io/docs/
Requires=network-online.target
After=network-online.target
ConditionFileNotEmpty=/etc/vault.d/vault.hcl
StartLimitIntervalSec=60
StartLimitBurst=3

[Service]
Type=notify
User=vault
Group=vault
ExecStart=/usr/local/bin/vault server -config=/etc/vault.d/vault.hcl
ExecReload=/bin/kill --signal HUP \$MAINPID
KillMode=process
Restart=on-failure
RestartSec=5
TimeoutStopSec=30
StartLimitInterval=60
StartLimitBurst=3

# File system isolation
ProtectSystem=full
ProtectHome=read-only
PrivateTmp=yes
PrivateDevices=yes

# Secure computing
NoNewPrivileges=yes
SecureBits=keep-caps
CapabilityBoundingSet=CAP_SYSLOG CAP_IPC_LOCK

    bash 
    # Enable PKI secrets engine for internal CA
vault secrets enable -path=pki pki

# Configure CA
vault secrets tune -max-lease-ttl=87600h pki

# Generate internal CA certificate
vault write -field=certificate pki/root/generate/internal \
    common_name="Internal CA" \
    issuer_name="internal-ca" \
    ttl=87600h > /opt/vault/tls/internal-ca.crt

# Configure certificate URLs
vault write pki/config/urls \
    issuing_certificates="https://vault.example.com:8200/v1/pki/ca" \
    crl_distribution_points="https://vault.example.com:8200/v1/pki/crl"

# Create intermediate CA
vault secrets enable -path=pki_int pki

vault secrets tune -max-lease-ttl=43800h pki_int

# Generate intermediate CSR
vault write -format=json pki_int/intermediate/generate/internal \
    common_name="Internal Intermediate CA" \
    issuer_name="internal-intermediate-ca" \
    | jq -r '.data.csr' > pki_intermediate.csr

# Sign intermediate certificate
vault write -format=json pki/root/sign-intermediate \
    issuer_ref="internal-ca" \
    csr=@pki_intermediate.csr \
    format=pem_bundle ttl="43800h" \
    | jq -r '.data.certificate' > intermediate.cert.pem

# Import signed certificate
vault write pki_int/intermediate/set-signed certificate=@intermediate.cert.pem

# Create role for service certificates
vault write pki_int/roles/service-role \
    issuer_ref="internal-intermediate-ca" \
    allowed_domains="example.com,internal.example.com" \
    allow_subdomains=true \
    max_ttl="72h" \
    generate_lease=true

# Create role for client certificates

    issuer_ref="internal-intermediate-ca" \
    allowed_domains="client.example.com" \
    allow_subdomains=false \
    client_flag=true \
    max_ttl="24h"

#!/bin/bash
BACKUP_DIR="/backup/vault"
DATE=$(date +%Y%m%d_%H%M%S)

mkdir -p ${BACKUP_DIR}/{snapshots,configs,certificates}

# Raft storage snapshot (Enterprise)

# Backup configuration files

    /etc/vault.d/ \
    /etc/systemd/system/vault.service

# Backup TLS certificates
tar -czf ${BACKUP_DIR}/certificates/vault-tls-${DATE}.tar.gz \
    /opt/vault/tls/

# Backup to cloud storage
# AWS S3
aws s3 cp ${BACKUP_DIR}/snapshots/vault-snapshot-${DATE}.snap s3://vault-backups/snapshots/
aws s3 cp ${BACKUP_DIR}/configs/vault-config-${DATE}.tar.gz s3://vault-backups/configs/

# Azure Blob Storage
az storage blob upload \
    --file ${BACKUP_DIR}/snapshots/vault-snapshot-${DATE}.snap \
    --container-name vault-backups \
    --name snapshots/vault-snapshot-${DATE}.snap

# Google Cloud Storage
gsutil cp ${BACKUP_DIR}/snapshots/vault-snapshot-${DATE}.snap gs://vault-backups/snapshots/

# Verify snapshot integrity
vault operator raft snapshot inspect ${BACKUP_DIR}/snapshots/vault-snapshot-${DATE}.snap

# Keep only last 30 backups locally
find ${BACKUP_DIR} -name "vault-*" -type f -mtime +30 -delete

# Encrypt backup files
gpg --symmetric --cipher-algo AES256 ${BACKUP_DIR}/snapshots/vault-snapshot-${DATE}.snap

echo "Vault backup completed: ${DATE}"
EOF

    Application Integration Examples

    Kubernetes Integration with Vault Agent

    bash 
    # Deploy Vault Agent as sidecar for Kubernetes workloads
cat > vault-agent-k8s.yaml <<EOF
apiVersion: v1
kind: ConfigMap
metadata:
  name: vault-agent-config
data:
  vault-agent.hcl: |
    exit_after_auth = false
    pid_file = "/home/vault/pidfile"

    auto_auth {
      method "kubernetes" {
        mount_path = "auth/kubernetes"
        config = {
          role = "myapp"
        }
      }

      sink "file" {
        config = {
          path = "/home/vault/.vault-token"
        }
      }
    }

    cache {
      use_auto_auth_token = true
    }

    listener "tcp" {
      address = "127.0.0.1:8080"
      tls_disable = true
    }

    vault {
      address = "https://vault.example.com:8200"
    }

    template {
      source      = "/vault/templates/database.conf.tpl"
      destination = "/vault/secrets/database.conf"
      perms       = 0640
      command     = "pkill -SIGHUP myapp"
    }
---
apiVersion: apps/v1
kind: Deployment
metadata:
  name: myapp-with-vault
spec:
  replicas: 3
  selector:
    matchLabels:
      app: myapp
  template:
    metadata:
      labels:
        app: myapp
    spec:
      serviceAccountName: vault-auth
      securityContext:
        runAsNonRoot: true
        runAsUser: 1000
        fsGroup: 1000
      containers:
      - name: vault-agent
        image: vault:latest
        command: ["vault", "agent", "-config=/vault/config/vault-agent.hcl"]
        volumeMounts:
        - name: vault-config
          mountPath: /vault/config
        - name: vault-secrets
          mountPath: /vault/secrets
        securityContext:
          allowPrivilegeEscalation: false
          readOnlyRootFilesystem: true
          capabilities:
            drop:
            - ALL
      - name: myapp
        image: myapp:latest
        volumeMounts:
        - name: vault-secrets
          mountPath: /app/config
          readOnly: true
        env:
        - name: DB_CONFIG_FILE
          value: "/app/config/database.conf"
        securityContext:
          allowPrivilegeEscalation: false
          readOnlyRootFilesystem: true
          capabilities:
            drop:
            - ALL
      volumes:
      - name: vault-config
        configMap:
          name: vault-agent-config
      - name: vault-secrets
        emptyDir:
          medium: Memory
EOF

kubectl apply -f vault-agent-k8s.yaml

    Advanced Audit Analysis

    bash 
    # Create audit log analysis script
sudo tee /usr/local/bin/vault-audit-analysis.sh > /dev/null <<'EOF'
#!/bin/bash
AUDIT_LOG="/opt/vault/logs/audit.log"
ANALYSIS_DIR="/var/log/vault-analysis"
DATE=$(date +%Y%m%d_%H%M%S)

mkdir -p ${ANALYSIS_DIR}

# Failed authentication attempts
echo "Failed Authentication Analysis - ${DATE}" > ${ANALYSIS_DIR}/failed-auth-${DATE}.txt
jq -r 'select(.type=="response" and .error != null) | [.time, .request.remote_address, .error] | @tsv' ${AUDIT_LOG} | tail -100 >> ${ANALYSIS_DIR}/failed-auth-${DATE}.txt

# Most active users
echo "Most Active Users - ${DATE}" > ${ANALYSIS_DIR}/active-users-${DATE}.txt
jq -r 'select(.type=="request" and .auth != null) | .auth.display_name' ${AUDIT_LOG} | sort | uniq -c | sort -nr | head -20 >> ${ANALYSIS_DIR}/active-users-${DATE}.txt

# Secret access patterns
echo "Secret Access Patterns - ${DATE}" > ${ANALYSIS_DIR}/secret-access-${DATE}.txt
jq -r 'select(.type=="request" and .request.path | test("^secret/data/")) | [.time, .auth.display_name, .request.path] | @tsv' ${AUDIT_LOG} | tail -100 >> ${ANALYSIS_DIR}/secret-access-${DATE}.txt

# Policy violations
echo "Policy Violations - ${DATE}" > ${ANALYSIS_DIR}/policy-violations-${DATE}.txt
jq -r 'select(.type=="response" and .error != null and (.error | test("permission denied"))) | [.time, .auth.display_name, .request.path, .error] | @tsv' ${AUDIT_LOG} | tail -50 >> ${ANALYSIS_DIR}/policy-violations-${DATE}.txt

# Generate summary report
cat > ${ANALYSIS_DIR}/audit-summary-${DATE}.txt <<EOL
Vault Audit Summary - ${DATE}
==============================

Total Requests: $(jq -s 'length' ${AUDIT_LOG})
Failed Authentications: $(jq -s 'map(select(.type=="response" and .error != null)) | length' ${AUDIT_LOG})
Policy Violations: $(jq -s 'map(select(.type=="response" and .error != null and (.error | test("permission denied")))) | length' ${AUDIT_LOG})
Unique Users: $(jq -r 'select(.type=="request" and .auth != null) | .auth.display_name' ${AUDIT_LOG} | sort -u | wc -l)

Top 5 Accessed Paths:
$(jq -r 'select(.type=="request") | .request.path' ${AUDIT_LOG} | sort | uniq -c | sort -nr | head -5)

Analysis completed at: $(date)
EOL

echo "Audit analysis completed. Reports in: ${ANALYSIS_DIR}/"
EOF

sudo chmod +x /usr/local/bin/vault-audit-analysis.sh

# Schedule weekly audit analysis
echo "0 6 * * 1 root /usr/local/bin/vault-audit-analysis.sh" | sudo tee -a /etc/crontab

    Verification and Testing

    Comprehensive Health Checks

    bash 
    # Create Vault health monitoring script
sudo tee /usr/local/bin/vault-health-check.sh > /dev/null <<'EOF'
#!/bin/bash
VAULT_ADDR="https://vault.example.com:8200"
HEALTH_LOG="/var/log/vault-health.log"

# Function to log with timestamp
log_message() {
    echo "$(date '+%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S') - $1" | tee -a ${HEALTH_LOG}
}

# Check Vault service status
if systemctl is-active vault >/dev/null 2>&1; then
    log_message "✓ Vault service is running"
else
    log_message "✗ Vault service is not running"
    exit 1
fi

# Check Vault HTTP health
if curl -k -sf ${VAULT_ADDR}/v1/sys/health >/dev/null 2>&1; then
    log_message "✓ Vault HTTP endpoint is responding"
else
    log_message "✗ Vault HTTP endpoint is not responding"
    exit 1
fi

# Check if Vault is sealed
SEALED_STATUS=$(vault status -format=json | jq -r .sealed)
if [ "$SEALED_STATUS" = "false" ]; then
    log_message "✓ Vault is unsealed"
else
    log_message "✗ Vault is sealed"
    exit 1
fi

# Check cluster status (if HA)
if vault status -format=json | jq -r .ha_enabled | grep -q "true"; then
    CLUSTER_HEALTH=$(vault operator raft list-peers -format=json | jq '.data.config.servers | length')
    log_message "✓ Cluster has ${CLUSTER_HEALTH} nodes"
fi

# Check replication status (Enterprise)
REPLICATION_STATUS=$(vault read -format=json sys/replication/status 2>/dev/null)
if [ $? -eq 0 ]; then
    DR_MODE=$(echo $REPLICATION_STATUS | jq -r .data.dr.mode)
    PERF_MODE=$(echo $REPLICATION_STATUS | jq -r .data.performance.mode)
    log_message "✓ Replication status - DR: ${DR_MODE}, Performance: ${PERF_MODE}"
fi

# Check auth methods
AUTH_METHODS=$(vault auth list -format=json | jq -r 'keys | length')
log_message "✓ ${AUTH_METHODS} authentication methods enabled"

# Check secrets engines
SECRETS_ENGINES=$(vault secrets list -format=json | jq -r 'keys | length')
log_message "✓ ${SECRETS_ENGINES} secrets engines enabled"

# Check policy count
POLICIES=$(vault policy list | wc -l)
log_message "✓ ${POLICIES} policies configured"

# Test secret read/write
TEST_SECRET="secret/health-check/test-$(date +%s)"
if vault kv put ${TEST_SECRET} test=true >/dev/null 2>&1; then
    if vault kv get ${TEST_SECRET} >/dev/null 2>&1; then
        log_message "✓ Secret read/write test passed"
        vault kv delete ${TEST_SECRET} >/dev/null 2>&1
    else
        log_message "✗ Secret read test failed"
    fi
else
    log_message "✗ Secret write test failed"
fi

# Check audit devices
AUDIT_DEVICES=$(vault audit list -format=json | jq -r 'keys | length')
log_message "✓ ${AUDIT_DEVICES} audit devices enabled"

log_message "Vault health check completed successfully"
EOF

sudo chmod +x /usr/local/bin/vault-health-check.sh

# Schedule health checks every 15 minutes
echo "*/15 * * * * root /usr/local/bin/vault-health-check.sh" | sudo tee -a /etc/crontab

    Security Validation Testing

    bash 
    # Create security testing script
sudo tee /usr/local/bin/vault-security-test.sh > /dev/null <<'EOF'
#!/bin/bash
VAULT_ADDR="https://vault.example.com:8200"
TEST_RESULTS="/tmp/vault-security-test-$(date +%Y%m%d_%H%M%S).txt"

echo "Vault Security Validation Test" > ${TEST_RESULTS}
echo "==============================" >> ${TEST_RESULTS}
echo "Date: $(date)" >> ${TEST_RESULTS}
echo "" >> ${TEST_RESULTS}

# Test 1: TLS Configuration
echo "Testing TLS Configuration..." >> ${TEST_RESULTS}
TLS_VERSION=$(openssl s_client -connect vault.example.com:8200 -brief 2>/dev/null | grep "Protocol version")
echo "TLS Version: ${TLS_VERSION}" >> ${TEST_RESULTS}

# Test 2: Authentication requirements
echo "Testing authentication requirements..." >> ${TEST_RESULTS}
UNAUTH_ACCESS=$(curl -k -s -w "%{http_code}" -o /dev/null ${VAULT_ADDR}/v1/secret/test)
if [ "$UNAUTH_ACCESS" = "403" ]; then
    echo "✓ Unauthenticated access properly denied" >> ${TEST_RESULTS}
else
    echo "✗ Unauthenticated access not properly restricted" >> ${TEST_RESULTS}
fi

# Test 3: Seal status
echo "Testing seal status..." >> ${TEST_RESULTS}
SEALED=$(vault status -format=json | jq -r .sealed)
if [ "$SEALED" = "false" ]; then
    echo "✓ Vault is properly unsealed" >> ${TEST_RESULTS}
else
    echo "✗ Vault is sealed" >> ${TEST_RESULTS}
fi

# Test 4: Audit logging
echo "Testing audit logging..." >> ${TEST_RESULTS}
AUDIT_COUNT=$(vault audit list -format=json | jq -r 'keys | length')
if [ "$AUDIT_COUNT" -gt "0" ]; then
    echo "✓ ${AUDIT_COUNT} audit devices enabled" >> ${TEST_RESULTS}
else
    echo "✗ No audit devices enabled" >> ${TEST_RESULTS}
fi

# Test 5: Policy enforcement
echo "Testing policy enforcement..." >> ${TEST_RESULTS}
vault token create -policy=developer -ttl=1m -format=json > /tmp/test-token.json
TEST_TOKEN=$(jq -r .auth.client_token /tmp/test-token.json)

# Test with limited token
VAULT_TOKEN=${TEST_TOKEN} vault auth -method=token ${TEST_TOKEN} >/dev/null 2>&1
LIMITED_ACCESS=$(VAULT_TOKEN=${TEST_TOKEN} curl -k -s -w "%{http_code}" -o /dev/null -H "X-Vault-Token: ${TEST_TOKEN}" ${VAULT_ADDR}/v1/sys/auth)
if [ "$LIMITED_ACCESS" = "403" ]; then
    echo "✓ Policy enforcement working correctly" >> ${TEST_RESULTS}
else
    echo "✗ Policy enforcement may be misconfigured" >> ${TEST_RESULTS}
fi

# Revoke test token
vault token revoke ${TEST_TOKEN}
rm /tmp/test-token.json

echo "" >> ${TEST_RESULTS}
echo "Security test completed at: $(date)" >> ${TEST_RESULTS}

echo "Security test completed. Results: ${TEST_RESULTS}"
EOF

sudo chmod +x /usr/local/bin/vault-security-test.sh

# Run security tests weekly
echo "0 8 * * 1 root /usr/local/bin/vault-security-test.sh" | sudo tee -a /etc/crontab

guides.name: wireguard
guides.readmeRaw:
# WireGuard Installation Guide

Modern, fast, and secure VPN solution using state-of-the-art cryptography. Essential tool for secure remote access, site-to-site connectivity, and privacy protection with minimal configuration complexity.

## Prerequisites

- Linux system with kernel 3.10+ (any modern distribution)
- Root or sudo access
- Static IP address or dynamic DNS
- UDP port 51820 available (default, configurable)
- Basic understanding of networking concepts

## Installation

### Ubuntu/Debian
```bash
# Update system packages
sudo apt update && sudo apt upgrade -y

# Install WireGuard
sudo apt install -y wireguard wireguard-tools

# For older Ubuntu versions (18.04)
sudo add-apt-repository ppa:wireguard/wireguard
sudo apt update
sudo apt install -y wireguard

# Install additional tools
sudo apt install -y qrencode resolvconf

# Verify installation
wg --version
modprobe wireguard && echo "WireGuard module loaded successfully"
```

### RHEL/CentOS/Rocky Linux/AlmaLinux
```bash
# Install EPEL repository
sudo yum install -y epel-release

# Install WireGuard
sudo yum install -y wireguard-tools

# For CentOS 7 (requires additional steps)
sudo yum install -y yum-plugin-elrepo
sudo yum install -y kmod-wireguard wireguard-tools

# Install additional tools
sudo yum install -y qrencode

# Enable IP forwarding
echo 'net.ipv4.ip_forward = 1' | sudo tee -a /etc/sysctl.conf
echo 'net.ipv6.conf.all.forwarding = 1' | sudo tee -a /etc/sysctl.conf
sudo sysctl -p
```

### Fedora
```bash
# Install WireGuard (included in kernel 5.6+)
sudo dnf install -y wireguard-tools qrencode

# Enable IP forwarding
echo 'net.ipv4.ip_forward = 1' | sudo tee -a /etc/sysctl.conf
sudo sysctl -p
```

### Arch Linux
```bash
# Install WireGuard
sudo pacman -Syu wireguard-tools qrencode

# Load WireGuard module
sudo modprobe wireguard

# Enable IP forwarding
echo 'net.ipv4.ip_forward = 1' | sudo tee -a /etc/sysctl.conf
sudo sysctl -p
```

## Server Configuration

### Generate Keys and Create Server Config
```bash
# Create WireGuard directory
sudo mkdir -p /etc/wireguard
sudo chmod 700 /etc/wireguard

# Generate server keys
cd /etc/wireguard
wg genkey | sudo tee server_private.key | wg pubkey | sudo tee server_public.key
sudo chmod 600 server_private.key

# Create server configuration
sudo tee /etc/wireguard/wg0.conf > /dev/null <<EOF
[Interface]
# Server configuration
PrivateKey = $(sudo cat server_private.key)
Address = 10.0.0.1/24, fd00::1/64
ListenPort = 51820
SaveConfig = true

# Network configuration
PostUp = iptables -A FORWARD -i %i -j ACCEPT; iptables -A FORWARD -o %i -j ACCEPT; iptables -t nat -A POSTROUTING -o eth0 -j MASQUERADE; ip6tables -A FORWARD -i %i -j ACCEPT; ip6tables -A FORWARD -o %i -j ACCEPT; ip6tables -t nat -A POSTROUTING -o eth0 -j MASQUERADE
```

```bash
CLIENT_PUBLIC_KEY=$(echo $CLIENT_PRIVATE_KEY | wg pubkey)

PublicKey = ${CLIENT_PUBLIC_KEY}
AllowedIPs = ${CLIENT_IP}
PersistentKeepalive = 25
PEER

cat > /tmp/${CLIENT_NAME}.conf <<CLIENT_CONFIG
[Interface]
PrivateKey = ${CLIENT_PRIVATE_KEY}
Address = ${CLIENT_IP}
DNS = 10.0.0.1, 1.1.1.1

[Peer]
PublicKey = ${SERVER_PUBLIC_KEY}
Endpoint = ${SERVER_PUBLIC_IP}:51820
AllowedIPs = 0.0.0.0/0, ::/0
PersistentKeepalive = 25
CLIENT_CONFIG
```

## Management and Automation

### WireGuard Management Script
```bash
sudo tee /usr/local/bin/wg-manager.sh > /dev/null <<'EOF'
#!/bin/bash

INTERFACE="wg0"
CONFIG_FILE="/etc/wireguard/${INTERFACE}.conf"
CLIENTS_DIR="/etc/wireguard/clients"
SERVER_PUBLIC_IP="${SERVER_PUBLIC_IP:-$(curl -s ipinfo.io/ip)}"
SERVER_PUBLIC_KEY="$(sudo cat /etc/wireguard/server_public.key)"

sudo mkdir -p ${CLIENTS_DIR}

case "${1}" in
    "add-client")
        CLIENT_NAME="${2}"
        if [ -z "$CLIENT_NAME" ]; then
            echo "Usage: $0 add-client <client_name>"
            exit 1
        fi
        
        # Generate client keys
        CLIENT_PRIVATE_KEY=$(wg genkey)
        CLIENT_PUBLIC_KEY=$(echo $CLIENT_PRIVATE_KEY | wg pubkey)
        
        # Get next available IP
        LAST_IP=$(grep "AllowedIPs" ${CONFIG_FILE} | grep -o "10\.0\.0\.[0-9]*" | sort -t. -k4 -n | tail -1 | cut -d. -f4)
        NEXT_IP=$((LAST_IP + 1))
        CLIENT_IP="10.0.0.${NEXT_IP}"
        
        # Add peer to server
        sudo wg set ${INTERFACE} peer ${CLIENT_PUBLIC_KEY} allowed-ips ${CLIENT_IP}/32
        
        # Save to config
        sudo tee -a ${CONFIG_FILE} > /dev/null <<PEER

[Peer]
# ${CLIENT_NAME} - $(date)
PublicKey = ${CLIENT_PUBLIC_KEY}
AllowedIPs = ${CLIENT_IP}/32
PersistentKeepalive = 25
PEER
        
        # Generate client config
        cat > ${CLIENTS_DIR}/${CLIENT_NAME}.conf <<CLIENT_CONFIG
[Interface]
PrivateKey = ${CLIENT_PRIVATE_KEY}
Address = ${CLIENT_IP}/32
DNS = 10.0.0.1

[Peer]
PublicKey = ${SERVER_PUBLIC_KEY}
Endpoint = ${SERVER_PUBLIC_IP}:51820
AllowedIPs = 0.0.0.0/0, ::/0
PersistentKeepalive = 25
CLIENT_CONFIG
        
        # Generate QR code
        echo "Client ${CLIENT_NAME} configuration:"
        qrencode -t ansiutf8 < ${CLIENTS_DIR}/${CLIENT_NAME}.conf
        echo "Configuration file: ${CLIENTS_DIR}/${CLIENT_NAME}.conf"
        ;;
        
    "remove-client")
        CLIENT_NAME="${2}"
        if [ -z "$CLIENT_NAME" ]; then
            echo "Usage: $0 remove-client <client_name>"
            exit 1
        fi
        
        CLIENT_PUBLIC_KEY=$(grep -A 3 "# ${CLIENT_NAME}" ${CONFIG_FILE} | grep "PublicKey" | cut -d' ' -f3)
        if [ -n "$CLIENT_PUBLIC_KEY" ]; then
            sudo wg set ${INTERFACE} peer ${CLIENT_PUBLIC_KEY} remove
            sudo sed -i "/# ${CLIENT_NAME}/,+3d" ${CONFIG_FILE}
            rm -f ${CLIENTS_DIR}/${CLIENT_NAME}.conf
            echo "Client ${CLIENT_NAME} removed"
        else
            echo "Client ${CLIENT_NAME} not found"
        fi
        ;;
        
    "list-clients")
        echo "Connected clients:"
        sudo wg show ${INTERFACE}
        echo ""
        echo "Configured clients:"
        grep "^# " ${CONFIG_FILE} | sed 's/# /- /'
        ;;
        
    "show-client")
        CLIENT_NAME="${2}"
        if [ -z "$CLIENT_NAME" ]; then
            echo "Usage: $0 show-client <client_name>"
            exit 1
        fi
        
        if [ -f "${CLIENTS_DIR}/${CLIENT_NAME}.conf" ]; then
            echo "Configuration for ${CLIENT_NAME}:"
            cat ${CLIENTS_DIR}/${CLIENT_NAME}.conf
            echo ""
            echo "QR Code:"
            qrencode -t ansiutf8 < ${CLIENTS_DIR}/${CLIENT_NAME}.conf
        else
            echo "Client ${CLIENT_NAME} not found"
        fi
        ;;
        
    "status")
        echo "WireGuard Status:"
        sudo systemctl status wg-quick@${INTERFACE}
        echo ""
        echo "Interface Details:"
        sudo wg show ${INTERFACE}
        echo ""
        echo "Interface Statistics:"
        sudo wg show ${INTERFACE} transfer
        ;;
        
    "restart")
        echo "Restarting WireGuard..."
        sudo systemctl restart wg-quick@${INTERFACE}
        echo "WireGuard restarted"
        ;;
        
    *)
        echo "WireGuard Management Script"
        echo "Usage: $0 {add-client|remove-client|list-clients|show-client|status|restart}"
        echo ""
        echo "Examples:"
        echo "  $0 add-client laptop1"
        echo "  $0 remove-client laptop1"  
        echo "  $0 show-client laptop1"
        echo "  $0 list-clients"
        echo "  $0 status"
        echo "  $0 restart"
        exit 1
        ;;
esac
EOF

sudo chmod +x /usr/local/bin/wg-manager.sh
```

```bash
#!/bin/bash
HEALTH_LOG="/var/log/wireguard-health.log"

log_message() {
    echo "$(date '+%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S') - $1" | tee -a ${HEALTH_LOG}
}

# Check WireGuard service

    log_message "✓ WireGuard service is running"
else
    log_message "✗ WireGuard service is not running"
    exit 1
fi

# Check interface status

    log_message "✓ WireGuard interface is up"
else
    log_message "✗ WireGuard interface is down"
fi

# Check connected peers
CONNECTED_PEERS=$(sudo wg show wg0 peers | wc -l)
ACTIVE_PEERS=$(sudo wg show wg0 latest-handshakes | awk '$2 > 0' | wc -l)
log_message "ℹ Connected peers: ${ACTIVE_PEERS}/${CONNECTED_PEERS}"

# Check traffic statistics
TRAFFIC_STATS=$(sudo wg show wg0 transfer)
log_message "ℹ Traffic statistics available: $(echo "$TRAFFIC_STATS" | wc -l) peers"

# Check listening port
if ss -ulpn | grep -q ":51820"; then
    log_message "✓ WireGuard is listening on port 51820"
else
    log_message "⚠ WireGuard not listening on expected port"
fi

# Check IP forwarding
IP_FORWARD=$(cat /proc/sys/net/ipv4/ip_forward)
if [ "$IP_FORWARD" = "1" ]; then
    log_message "✓ IP forwarding is enabled"
else
    log_message "✗ IP forwarding is disabled"
fi

log_message "WireGuard health check completed"
EOF
```

### Backup and Configuration Management
```bash
sudo tee /usr/local/bin/wireguard-backup.sh > /dev/null <<'EOF'
#!/bin/bash
BACKUP_DIR="/backup/wireguard"
DATE=$(date +%Y%m%d_%H%M%S)

mkdir -p ${BACKUP_DIR}/{configs,clients}

echo "Starting WireGuard backup..."

# Backup server configuration
cp /etc/wireguard/wg0.conf ${BACKUP_DIR}/configs/wg0-${DATE}.conf

# Backup client configurations
if [ -d "/etc/wireguard/clients" ]; then
    tar -czf ${BACKUP_DIR}/clients/clients-${DATE}.tar.gz -C /etc/wireguard clients/
fi

# Backup keys
tar -czf ${BACKUP_DIR}/configs/keys-${DATE}.tar.gz -C /etc/wireguard *.key

# Upload to cloud storage (encrypted)
gpg --symmetric --cipher-algo AES256 --compress-algo 1 --s2k-mode 3 \
    --s2k-digest-algo SHA512 --s2k-count 65536 \
    --output ${BACKUP_DIR}/wireguard-backup-${DATE}.tar.gz.gpg \
    --compress-level 9 \
    <(tar -czf - -C ${BACKUP_DIR} .)

# Upload encrypted backup
aws s3 cp ${BACKUP_DIR}/wireguard-backup-${DATE}.tar.gz.gpg s3://wireguard-backups/

# Keep only last 30 backups
find ${BACKUP_DIR} -name "wireguard-*" -type f -mtime +30 -delete

echo "WireGuard backup completed: ${DATE}"
EOF

sudo chmod +x /usr/local/bin/wireguard-backup.sh

# Schedule daily backups
echo "0 3 * * * root /usr/local/bin/wireguard-backup.sh" | sudo tee -a /etc/crontab
```

WireGuard Installation Guide

Modern, fast, and secure VPN solution using state-of-the-art cryptography. Essential tool for secure remote access, site-to-site connectivity, and privacy protection with minimal configuration complexity.

Prerequisites

  • Linux system with kernel 3.10+ (any modern distribution)
  • Root or sudo access
  • Static IP address or dynamic DNS
  • UDP port 51820 available (default, configurable)
  • Basic understanding of networking concepts

    • Installation

    Ubuntu/Debian

    bash 
    # Update system packages
sudo apt update && sudo apt upgrade -y

# Install WireGuard
sudo apt install -y wireguard wireguard-tools

# For older Ubuntu versions (18.04)
sudo add-apt-repository ppa:wireguard/wireguard
sudo apt update
sudo apt install -y wireguard

# Install additional tools
sudo apt install -y qrencode resolvconf

# Verify installation
wg --version
modprobe wireguard && echo "WireGuard module loaded successfully"

    bash 
    # Install EPEL repository

# Install WireGuard

sudo yum install -y kmod-wireguard wireguard-tools

# Install additional tools
sudo yum install -y qrencode

# Enable IP forwarding
echo 'net.ipv4.ip_forward = 1' | sudo tee -a /etc/sysctl.conf

sudo sysctl -p

    Generate Keys and Create Server Config

    bash 
    # Create WireGuard directory
sudo mkdir -p /etc/wireguard
sudo chmod 700 /etc/wireguard

# Generate server keys
cd /etc/wireguard
wg genkey | sudo tee server_private.key | wg pubkey | sudo tee server_public.key
sudo chmod 600 server_private.key

# Create server configuration
sudo tee /etc/wireguard/wg0.conf > /dev/null <<EOF
[Interface]
# Server configuration
PrivateKey = $(sudo cat server_private.key)
Address = 10.0.0.1/24, fd00::1/64
ListenPort = 51820
SaveConfig = true

# Network configuration
PostUp = iptables -A FORWARD -i %i -j ACCEPT; iptables -A FORWARD -o %i -j ACCEPT; iptables -t nat -A POSTROUTING -o eth0 -j MASQUERADE; ip6tables -A FORWARD -i %i -j ACCEPT; ip6tables -A FORWARD -o %i -j ACCEPT; ip6tables -t nat -A POSTROUTING -o eth0 -j MASQUERADE
PostDown = iptables -D FORWARD -i %i -j ACCEPT; iptables -D FORWARD -o %i -j ACCEPT; iptables -t nat -D POSTROUTING -o eth0 -j MASQUERADE; ip6tables -D FORWARD -i %i -j ACCEPT; ip6tables -D FORWARD -o %i -j ACCEPT; ip6tables -t nat -D POSTROUTING -o eth0 -j MASQUERADE

# DNS servers (optional)
DNS = 1.1.1.1, 8.8.8.8

# Client configurations will be added here automatically
# [Peer] sections for each client
EOF

sudo chmod 600 /etc/wireguard/wg0.conf

    Advanced Server Configuration

    bash 
    # Create production server configuration with security
sudo tee /etc/wireguard/wg0.conf > /dev/null <<EOF
[Interface]
# Server identity
PrivateKey = $(sudo cat server_private.key)
Address = 10.0.0.1/24
ListenPort = 51820
SaveConfig = false  # Disable for security in production

# Network forwarding and NAT
PostUp = iptables -A FORWARD -i %i -j ACCEPT; iptables -A FORWARD -o %i -j ACCEPT; iptables -t nat -A POSTROUTING -o eth0 -j MASQUERADE
PostUp = ip6tables -A FORWARD -i %i -j ACCEPT; ip6tables -A FORWARD -o %i -j ACCEPT; ip6tables -t nat -A POSTROUTING -o eth0 -j MASQUERADE
PostDown = iptables -D FORWARD -i %i -j ACCEPT; iptables -D FORWARD -o %i -j ACCEPT; iptables -t nat -D POSTROUTING -o eth0 -j MASQUERADE
PostDown = ip6tables -D FORWARD -i %i -j ACCEPT; ip6tables -D FORWARD -o %i -j ACCEPT; ip6tables -t nat -D POSTROUTING -o eth0 -j MASQUERADE

# Security: Block private networks (adjust as needed)
PostUp = iptables -I FORWARD -s 10.0.0.0/8 -d 192.168.1.0/24 -j DROP
PostUp = iptables -I FORWARD -s 10.0.0.0/8 -d 172.16.0.0/12 -j DROP

# DNS configuration
DNS = 10.0.0.1  # Use Pi-hole or local DNS

# Example client configurations
[Peer]
# Client 1 - Admin laptop
PublicKey = client1_public_key_here
AllowedIPs = 10.0.0.2/32
PersistentKeepalive = 25

[Peer]  
# Client 2 - Mobile device
PublicKey = client2_public_key_here
AllowedIPs = 10.0.0.3/32
PersistentKeepalive = 25

[Peer]
# Client 3 - Site-to-site (branch office)
PublicKey = site_public_key_here
AllowedIPs = 10.0.0.0/24, 192.168.100.0/24
Endpoint = branch.example.com:51820
PersistentKeepalive = 25
EOF

    Client Configuration

    Generate Client Configurations

    bash 
    # Create client configuration generator script
sudo tee /usr/local/bin/wg-add-client.sh > /dev/null <<'EOF'
#!/bin/bash
CLIENT_NAME="${1}"
SERVER_PUBLIC_IP="${2:-your-server-public-ip}"
SERVER_PUBLIC_KEY="$(sudo cat /etc/wireguard/server_public.key)"

if [ -z "$CLIENT_NAME" ]; then
    echo "Usage: $0 <client_name> [server_public_ip]"
    echo "Example: $0 laptop1 203.0.113.1"
    exit 1
fi

# Get next available IP
LAST_IP=$(grep "AllowedIPs" /etc/wireguard/wg0.conf | grep -o "10\.0\.0\.[0-9]*" | sort -t. -k4 -n | tail -1 | cut -d. -f4)
NEXT_IP=$((LAST_IP + 1))
CLIENT_IP="10.0.0.${NEXT_IP}/32"

# Generate client keys
CLIENT_PRIVATE_KEY=$(wg genkey)
CLIENT_PUBLIC_KEY=$(echo $CLIENT_PRIVATE_KEY | wg pubkey)

# Add peer to server configuration
sudo tee -a /etc/wireguard/wg0.conf > /dev/null <<PEER

[Peer]
# ${CLIENT_NAME}
PublicKey = ${CLIENT_PUBLIC_KEY}
AllowedIPs = ${CLIENT_IP}
PersistentKeepalive = 25
PEER

# Generate client configuration
cat > /tmp/${CLIENT_NAME}.conf <<CLIENT_CONFIG
[Interface]
PrivateKey = ${CLIENT_PRIVATE_KEY}
Address = ${CLIENT_IP}
DNS = 10.0.0.1, 1.1.1.1

[Peer]
PublicKey = ${SERVER_PUBLIC_KEY}
Endpoint = ${SERVER_PUBLIC_IP}:51820
AllowedIPs = 0.0.0.0/0, ::/0
PersistentKeepalive = 25
CLIENT_CONFIG

# Generate QR code for mobile devices
qrencode -t ansiutf8 < /tmp/${CLIENT_NAME}.conf

echo "Client configuration created: /tmp/${CLIENT_NAME}.conf"
echo "Add to server with: sudo wg addconf wg0 <(echo '[Peer]'; echo 'PublicKey = ${CLIENT_PUBLIC_KEY}'; echo 'AllowedIPs = ${CLIENT_IP}')"
EOF

sudo chmod +x /usr/local/bin/wg-add-client.sh

# Example: Add a client
# sudo /usr/local/bin/wg-add-client.sh laptop1 your-server-ip

    Client Examples

    bash 
    # Mobile device configuration
cat > mobile-client.conf <<EOF
[Interface]
PrivateKey = mobile_device_private_key
Address = 10.0.0.10/32
DNS = 10.0.0.1

[Peer]
PublicKey = server_public_key_here
Endpoint = vpn.example.com:51820

EOF

# Site-to-site configuration (branch office)
cat > branch-office.conf <<EOF
[Interface]
PrivateKey = branch_office_private_key
Address = 10.0.0.100/32
PostUp = iptables -A FORWARD -i %i -j ACCEPT; iptables -A FORWARD -o %i -j ACCEPT; iptables -t nat -A POSTROUTING -o eth0 -j MASQUERADE
PostDown = iptables -D FORWARD -i %i -j ACCEPT; iptables -D FORWARD -o %i -j ACCEPT; iptables -t nat -D POSTROUTING -o eth0 -j MASQUERADE

[Peer]
PublicKey = server_public_key_here
Endpoint = vpn.example.com:51820
AllowedIPs = 10.0.0.0/24, 192.168.1.0/24

    Service Management and Security

    SystemD Service

    bash 
    # Enable WireGuard interface as systemd service
sudo systemctl enable wg-quick@wg0
sudo systemctl start wg-quick@wg0

# Check status
sudo systemctl status wg-quick@wg0
sudo wg show

# Alternative: Manual management
sudo wg-quick up wg0
sudo wg-quick down wg0

    Firewall Configuration

    bash 
    # Configure UFW for WireGuard
sudo ufw allow 51820/udp comment 'WireGuard VPN'
sudo ufw allow from 10.0.0.0/24 comment 'WireGuard clients'

# For internal network access
sudo ufw allow from 10.0.0.0/24 to 192.168.1.0/24

# Firewalld configuration (RHEL/CentOS)
sudo firewall-cmd --permanent --add-port=51820/udp
sudo firewall-cmd --permanent --add-rich-rule='rule family=ipv4 source address=10.0.0.0/24 accept'
sudo firewall-cmd --reload

# Direct iptables rules
sudo iptables -A INPUT -p udp --dport 51820 -j ACCEPT
sudo iptables -A FORWARD -i wg0 -j ACCEPT
sudo iptables -A FORWARD -o wg0 -j ACCEPT
sudo iptables -t nat -A POSTROUTING -o eth0 -j MASQUERADE

    Security Hardening

    bash 
    # Configure advanced security features
sudo tee /etc/wireguard/wg0.conf > /dev/null <<EOF
[Interface]
PrivateKey = $(sudo cat server_private.key)
Address = 10.0.0.1/24
ListenPort = 51820

# Security: Change default port
# ListenPort = 41194

# DNS security
DNS = 10.0.0.1  # Use Pi-hole for ad blocking

# Advanced security rules
PostUp = iptables -A FORWARD -i %i -j ACCEPT
PostUp = iptables -A FORWARD -o %i -j ACCEPT
PostUp = iptables -t nat -A POSTROUTING -o eth0 -j MASQUERADE

# Block access to local network (security measure)
PostUp = iptables -I FORWARD -s 10.0.0.0/24 -d 192.168.1.0/24 -j DROP
PostUp = iptables -I FORWARD -s 10.0.0.0/24 -d 172.16.0.0/12 -j DROP
PostUp = iptables -I FORWARD -s 10.0.0.0/24 -d 10.0.0.0/8 -j DROP

# Allow specific services only
PostUp = iptables -I FORWARD -s 10.0.0.0/24 -d 192.168.1.100 -p tcp --dport 22 -j ACCEPT    # SSH to server
PostUp = iptables -I FORWARD -s 10.0.0.0/24 -d 192.168.1.101 -p tcp --dport 443 -j ACCEPT  # HTTPS to web services

PostDown = iptables -D FORWARD -i %i -j ACCEPT
PostDown = iptables -D FORWARD -o %i -j ACCEPT
PostDown = iptables -t nat -D POSTROUTING -o eth0 -j MASQUERADE
EOF

    Management and Automation

    WireGuard Management Script

    bash 
    sudo tee /usr/local/bin/wg-manager.sh > /dev/null <<'EOF'
#!/bin/bash

INTERFACE="wg0"
CONFIG_FILE="/etc/wireguard/${INTERFACE}.conf"
CLIENTS_DIR="/etc/wireguard/clients"
SERVER_PUBLIC_IP="${SERVER_PUBLIC_IP:-$(curl -s ipinfo.io/ip)}"
SERVER_PUBLIC_KEY="$(sudo cat /etc/wireguard/server_public.key)"

sudo mkdir -p ${CLIENTS_DIR}

case "${1}" in
    "add-client")
        CLIENT_NAME="${2}"
        if [ -z "$CLIENT_NAME" ]; then
            echo "Usage: $0 add-client <client_name>"
            exit 1
        fi
        
        # Generate client keys
        CLIENT_PRIVATE_KEY=$(wg genkey)
        CLIENT_PUBLIC_KEY=$(echo $CLIENT_PRIVATE_KEY | wg pubkey)
        
        # Get next available IP
        LAST_IP=$(grep "AllowedIPs" ${CONFIG_FILE} | grep -o "10\.0\.0\.[0-9]*" | sort -t. -k4 -n | tail -1 | cut -d. -f4)
        NEXT_IP=$((LAST_IP + 1))
        CLIENT_IP="10.0.0.${NEXT_IP}"
        
        # Add peer to server
        sudo wg set ${INTERFACE} peer ${CLIENT_PUBLIC_KEY} allowed-ips ${CLIENT_IP}/32
        
        # Save to config
        sudo tee -a ${CONFIG_FILE} > /dev/null <<PEER

[Peer]
# ${CLIENT_NAME} - $(date)
PublicKey = ${CLIENT_PUBLIC_KEY}
AllowedIPs = ${CLIENT_IP}/32
PersistentKeepalive = 25
PEER
        
        # Generate client config
        cat > ${CLIENTS_DIR}/${CLIENT_NAME}.conf <<CLIENT_CONFIG
[Interface]
PrivateKey = ${CLIENT_PRIVATE_KEY}
Address = ${CLIENT_IP}/32
DNS = 10.0.0.1

[Peer]
PublicKey = ${SERVER_PUBLIC_KEY}
Endpoint = ${SERVER_PUBLIC_IP}:51820
AllowedIPs = 0.0.0.0/0, ::/0
PersistentKeepalive = 25
CLIENT_CONFIG
        
        # Generate QR code
        echo "Client ${CLIENT_NAME} configuration:"
        qrencode -t ansiutf8 < ${CLIENTS_DIR}/${CLIENT_NAME}.conf
        echo "Configuration file: ${CLIENTS_DIR}/${CLIENT_NAME}.conf"
        ;;
        
    "remove-client")
        CLIENT_NAME="${2}"
        if [ -z "$CLIENT_NAME" ]; then
            echo "Usage: $0 remove-client <client_name>"
            exit 1
        fi
        
        CLIENT_PUBLIC_KEY=$(grep -A 3 "# ${CLIENT_NAME}" ${CONFIG_FILE} | grep "PublicKey" | cut -d' ' -f3)
        if [ -n "$CLIENT_PUBLIC_KEY" ]; then
            sudo wg set ${INTERFACE} peer ${CLIENT_PUBLIC_KEY} remove
            sudo sed -i "/# ${CLIENT_NAME}/,+3d" ${CONFIG_FILE}
            rm -f ${CLIENTS_DIR}/${CLIENT_NAME}.conf
            echo "Client ${CLIENT_NAME} removed"
        else
            echo "Client ${CLIENT_NAME} not found"
        fi
        ;;
        
    "list-clients")
        echo "Connected clients:"
        sudo wg show ${INTERFACE}
        echo ""
        echo "Configured clients:"
        grep "^# " ${CONFIG_FILE} | sed 's/# /- /'
        ;;
        
    "show-client")
        CLIENT_NAME="${2}"
        if [ -z "$CLIENT_NAME" ]; then
            echo "Usage: $0 show-client <client_name>"
            exit 1
        fi
        
        if [ -f "${CLIENTS_DIR}/${CLIENT_NAME}.conf" ]; then
            echo "Configuration for ${CLIENT_NAME}:"
            cat ${CLIENTS_DIR}/${CLIENT_NAME}.conf
            echo ""
            echo "QR Code:"
            qrencode -t ansiutf8 < ${CLIENTS_DIR}/${CLIENT_NAME}.conf
        else
            echo "Client ${CLIENT_NAME} not found"
        fi
        ;;
        
    "status")
        echo "WireGuard Status:"
        sudo systemctl status wg-quick@${INTERFACE}
        echo ""
        echo "Interface Details:"
        sudo wg show ${INTERFACE}
        echo ""
        echo "Interface Statistics:"
        sudo wg show ${INTERFACE} transfer
        ;;
        
    "restart")
        echo "Restarting WireGuard..."
        sudo systemctl restart wg-quick@${INTERFACE}
        echo "WireGuard restarted"
        ;;
        
    *)
        echo "WireGuard Management Script"
        echo "Usage: $0 {add-client|remove-client|list-clients|show-client|status|restart}"
        echo ""
        echo "Examples:"
        echo "  $0 add-client laptop1"
        echo "  $0 remove-client laptop1"  
        echo "  $0 show-client laptop1"
        echo "  $0 list-clients"
        echo "  $0 status"
        echo "  $0 restart"
        exit 1
        ;;
esac
EOF

sudo chmod +x /usr/local/bin/wg-manager.sh

    Web UI (WireGuard Easy)

    bash 
    # Install WireGuard Easy (web management interface)
mkdir -p ~/wg-easy
cd ~/wg-easy

cat > docker-compose.yml <<EOF
version: '3.8'

services:
  wg-easy:
    image: weejewel/wg-easy:latest
    container_name: wg-easy
    restart: unless-stopped

      - "51821:51821/udp"  # WireGuard port

    volumes:

networks:

    driver: bridge

# Start WG-Easy
docker-compose up -d

# Access web interface at http://localhost:51822

    Monitoring and Maintenance

    Health Monitoring

    bash 
    sudo tee /usr/local/bin/wireguard-health.sh > /dev/null <<'EOF'
#!/bin/bash
HEALTH_LOG="/var/log/wireguard-health.log"

log_message() {
    echo "$(date '+%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S') - $1" | tee -a ${HEALTH_LOG}
}

# Check WireGuard service
if systemctl is-active wg-quick@wg0 >/dev/null 2>&1; then
    log_message "✓ WireGuard service is running"
else
    log_message "✗ WireGuard service is not running"
    exit 1
fi

# Check interface status
if ip link show wg0 >/dev/null 2>&1; then
    log_message "✓ WireGuard interface is up"
else
    log_message "✗ WireGuard interface is down"
fi

# Check connected peers
CONNECTED_PEERS=$(sudo wg show wg0 peers | wc -l)
ACTIVE_PEERS=$(sudo wg show wg0 latest-handshakes | awk '$2 > 0' | wc -l)
log_message "ℹ Connected peers: ${ACTIVE_PEERS}/${CONNECTED_PEERS}"

# Check traffic statistics
TRAFFIC_STATS=$(sudo wg show wg0 transfer)
log_message "ℹ Traffic statistics available: $(echo "$TRAFFIC_STATS" | wc -l) peers"

# Check listening port
if ss -ulpn | grep -q ":51820"; then
    log_message "✓ WireGuard is listening on port 51820"
else
    log_message "⚠ WireGuard not listening on expected port"
fi

# Check IP forwarding
IP_FORWARD=$(cat /proc/sys/net/ipv4/ip_forward)
if [ "$IP_FORWARD" = "1" ]; then
    log_message "✓ IP forwarding is enabled"
else
    log_message "✗ IP forwarding is disabled"
fi

log_message "WireGuard health check completed"
EOF

sudo chmod +x /usr/local/bin/wireguard-health.sh

# Schedule health checks every 10 minutes
echo "*/10 * * * * root /usr/local/bin/wireguard-health.sh" | sudo tee -a /etc/crontab

    Backup and Configuration Management

    bash 
    sudo tee /usr/local/bin/wireguard-backup.sh > /dev/null <<'EOF'
#!/bin/bash
BACKUP_DIR="/backup/wireguard"
DATE=$(date +%Y%m%d_%H%M%S)

mkdir -p ${BACKUP_DIR}/{configs,clients}

echo "Starting WireGuard backup..."

# Backup server configuration
cp /etc/wireguard/wg0.conf ${BACKUP_DIR}/configs/wg0-${DATE}.conf

# Backup client configurations
if [ -d "/etc/wireguard/clients" ]; then
    tar -czf ${BACKUP_DIR}/clients/clients-${DATE}.tar.gz -C /etc/wireguard clients/
fi

# Backup keys
tar -czf ${BACKUP_DIR}/configs/keys-${DATE}.tar.gz -C /etc/wireguard *.key

# Upload to cloud storage (encrypted)
gpg --symmetric --cipher-algo AES256 --compress-algo 1 --s2k-mode 3 \
    --s2k-digest-algo SHA512 --s2k-count 65536 \
    --output ${BACKUP_DIR}/wireguard-backup-${DATE}.tar.gz.gpg \
    --compress-level 9 \
    <(tar -czf - -C ${BACKUP_DIR} .)

# Upload encrypted backup
aws s3 cp ${BACKUP_DIR}/wireguard-backup-${DATE}.tar.gz.gpg s3://wireguard-backups/

# Keep only last 30 backups
find ${BACKUP_DIR} -name "wireguard-*" -type f -mtime +30 -delete

echo "WireGuard backup completed: ${DATE}"
EOF

sudo chmod +x /usr/local/bin/wireguard-backup.sh

# Schedule daily backups
echo "0 3 * * * root /usr/local/bin/wireguard-backup.sh" | sudo tee -a /etc/crontab

    Advanced Features

    Site-to-Site VPN

    bash 
    # Configure site-to-site VPN between offices
# Office A (Main) - 192.168.1.0/24
# Office B (Branch) - 192.168.2.0/24

# Main office WireGuard config
sudo tee /etc/wireguard/site-to-site.conf > /dev/null <<EOF
[Interface]
PrivateKey = main_office_private_key
Address = 172.16.0.1/30
ListenPort = 51820

# Route traffic between sites
PostUp = ip route add 192.168.2.0/24 dev %i
PostUp = iptables -A FORWARD -i %i -o eth0 -s 192.168.2.0/24 -d 192.168.1.0/24 -j ACCEPT
PostUp = iptables -A FORWARD -i eth0 -o %i -s 192.168.1.0/24 -d 192.168.2.0/24 -j ACCEPT

PostDown = ip route del 192.168.2.0/24 dev %i
PostDown = iptables -D FORWARD -i %i -o eth0 -s 192.168.2.0/24 -d 192.168.1.0/24 -j ACCEPT
PostDown = iptables -D FORWARD -i eth0 -o %i -s 192.168.1.0/24 -d 192.168.2.0/24 -j ACCEPT

[Peer]
# Branch Office
PublicKey = branch_office_public_key
Endpoint = branch.example.com:51820
AllowedIPs = 172.16.0.2/32, 192.168.2.0/24
PersistentKeepalive = 25
EOF

    Load Balancing and Failover

    bash 
    # Configure multiple WireGuard servers for redundancy
# Client configuration with multiple peers
cat > multi-server-client.conf <<EOF
[Interface]
PrivateKey = client_private_key
Address = 10.0.0.10/32
DNS = 1.1.1.1, 8.8.8.8

# Primary server
[Peer]
PublicKey = primary_server_public_key
Endpoint = vpn1.example.com:51820
AllowedIPs = 0.0.0.0/1, 128.0.0.0/1
PersistentKeepalive = 25

# Backup server (different IP range to avoid conflicts)
[Peer]
PublicKey = backup_server_public_key
Endpoint = vpn2.example.com:51820
AllowedIPs = 10.1.0.0/24
PersistentKeepalive = 25
EOF

    Troubleshooting

    Common Issues and Solutions

    bash 
    # Check WireGuard status
sudo systemctl status wg-quick@wg0
sudo wg show

# Check interface configuration
ip addr show wg0
ip route show table all | grep wg0

# Test connectivity
ping -c 4 10.0.0.1  # Server IP from client
ping -c 4 10.0.0.2  # Client IP from server

# Check logs

dmesg | grep wireguard

# Debug handshake issues

sudo wg show wg0 transfer

sudo wg show wg0 allowed-ips

# Check MTU issues

# Performance testing
iperf3 -s -p 5201  # On server
iperf3 -c 10.0.0.1 -p 5201  # On client

# Configuration validation

# Check routing table
ip route show table all
ip rule show

# Network troubleshooting
traceroute -I 8.8.8.8  # Test route through VPN
ss -tulpn | grep 51820
netstat -tulpn | grep 51820

    Advanced Debugging

echo 'module wireguard +p' | sudo tee /sys/kernel/debug/dynamic_debug/control

# Monitor kernel messages

# Packet capture

WordPress Installation Guide

World's most popular content management system (CMS) powering over 40% of websites globally. Complete guide for secure, high-performance WordPress deployment with modern stack configurations.

Prerequisites

  • Linux system (any modern distribution)
  • 2GB RAM minimum, 4GB+ recommended for production
  • Web server (NGINX recommended, Apache supported)
  • PHP 8.1+ (8.2+ recommended)
  • MySQL 8.0+ or MariaDB 10.6+
  • SSL certificate for HTTPS
  • Domain name for production deployment

    • Installation Methods

    LEMP Stack (Recommended for 2024)

    #### Ubuntu/Debian LEMP Setup

    bash 
    # Update system
sudo apt update && sudo apt upgrade -y

# Install NGINX
sudo apt install -y nginx

# Install MySQL/MariaDB
sudo apt install -y mariadb-server mariadb-client

# Install PHP 8.2 and essential extensions
sudo apt install -y php8.2-fpm php8.2-mysql php8.2-curl php8.2-gd php8.2-mbstring php8.2-xml php8.2-xmlrpc php8.2-soap php8.2-intl php8.2-zip php8.2-bcmath php8.2-imagick php8.2-cli php8.2-dev php8.2-imap php8.2-opcache

# Install additional performance tools
sudo apt install -y redis-server memcached unzip curl wget

# Enable and start services
sudo systemctl enable --now nginx mariadb php8.2-fpm redis-server

# Secure MySQL installation
sudo mysql_secure_installation

# Configure firewall
sudo ufw allow 'Nginx Full'
sudo ufw allow OpenSSH
sudo ufw enable

    #### RHEL/CentOS/Rocky Linux LEMP Setup

    bash 
    # Install EPEL and Remi repositories
sudo yum install -y epel-release

tail -f /var/log/nginx/error.log

# Database query analysis
sudo -u www-data wp db query "SHOW FULL PROCESSLIST;"
sudo -u www-data wp db query "SHOW STATUS LIKE 'Slow_queries';"

# Memory profiling
sudo -u www-data wp eval 'echo "Memory usage: " . memory_get_usage(true) / 1024 / 1024 . " MB\n";'

# Plugin profiling
sudo -u www-data wp plugin list --status=active
sudo -u www-data wp eval 'foreach(get_option("active_plugins") as $p) { echo $p . "\n"; }'

# Theme debugging
sudo -u www-data wp theme status
sudo -u www-data wp eval 'echo get_template_directory() . "\n";'

# xen-orchestra - CentOS

```bash
curl --silent --location https://rpm.nodesource.com/setup_8.x | sudo bash -
curl --silent --location https://dl.yarnpkg.com/rpm/yarn.repo | sudo tee /etc/yum.repos.d/yarn.repo

yum groupinstall 'Development Tools'
yum -y install epel-release gcc gcc-c++ automake libpng-devel git python redis nodejs yarn
systemctl enable --now redis

git clone -b master http://github.com/vatesfr/xen-orchestra
yarn
yarn build
cd packages/xo-server
cp sample.config.yaml .xo-server.yaml
vi .xo-server.yaml # mounts: '/': '../xo-web/dist/'
yarn start 
```

## xen-orchestra - Debian

```bash
curl -sL https://deb.nodesource.com/setup_8.x | sudo -E bash -
curl -sS https://dl.yarnpkg.com/debian/pubkey.gpg | sudo apt-key add -
echo "deb https://dl.yarnpkg.com/debian/ stable main" | sudo tee /etc/apt/sources.list.d/yarn.list
sudo apt update
sudo apt-get install -y nodejs yarn build-essential redis-server libpng-dev git python-minimal libvhdi-utils lvm2

git clone -b master http://github.com/vatesfr/xen-orchestra
cd xen-orchestra
yarn
yarn build
cd packages/xo-server
cp sample.config.yaml .xo-server.yaml
vi .xo-server.yaml # mounts: '/': '../xo-web/dist/'
yarn start 
```

## xen-orchestra - Updating

```bash
cd /opt/xen-orchestra/
sudo git pull --ff-only
sudo yarn
sudo yarn build
```
